subject: RE: [junit] Why no assertNotEquals()
msgSnippet: ... This is what EqualsTester does. You provide three (or four) instances with the following properties: a.equals(b) should be true a.equals(c) should be false
messageBody:
>So said Demyanovich, Craig - Apogent on 4/25/2003 --------------------
>I've never thought about testing equals() this way, simple idea though it
>is. I test equals() according to its contract as specified in its
>documentation in Object. Joshua Bloch also explains it well in his book,
>_Effective Java_. What I test for, then, are the following: reflexivity,
>symmetry, transitivity, consistency and "non-nullity," to use Bloch's
>terms.
>I create three identical instances of a class and use them in various
>asserts. I could share if you like. I'll have to think about what value
>your idea might bring to my test.

This is what EqualsTester does. You provide three (or four) instances with the following properties:

a.equals(b) should be true
a.equals(c) should be false
a.equals(d) should be false because d's type is a subclass of a's type

If a's type is "final", then d should be null and vice versa.

EqualsTester then runs through the full contract of Object#equals().

Take care.


J. B. Rainsberger,
President, Diaspar Software Services
